section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation
section.content: These regulations may be cited as the Police (Discipline) Regulations.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these regulations, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: appropriate tribunal (適當審裁體) in relation to an inspector has the meaning assigned to it by regulation 16, and in relation to a junior police officer has the meaning assigned to it by regulation 4;
barrister (大律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159); (L.N. 59 of 2012)

def.name: DefaulterReport
def.leadIn: Defaulter Report (違紀者報告) means the record of the case against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a police officer against whom a disciplinary charge is intended to be laid under regulation 5(1) or 17(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a defaulter; (L.N. 59 of 2012)

section.def: defence representative (辯護代表) means a person specified in regulation 7B(1)(a), (b), (c) or (d) or 18C(1)(a), (b), (c) or (d) who represents a defaulter at a hearing; (L.N. 59 of 2012)
disciplinary offence (違紀行為) means a disciplinary offence specified in regulation 3(2); (L.N. 59 of 2012)
Force Discipline Officer (警隊紀律主任) means a police officer appointed by the Commissioner to be Force Discipline Officer for the purposes of these regulations; (L.N. 305 of 1982)
hearing (聆訊) means a hearing conducted in respect of a disciplinary offence; (L.N. 59 of 2012)
junior police officer (初級警務人員) means a police officer below the rank of inspector;
official record of proceedings (程序正式紀錄) means a written record of the proceedings of a hearing made under regulation 10A(1) or 22A(1); (L.N. 59 of 2012)
senior police officer (高級警務人員) means a chief superintendent, assistant commissioner or senior assistant commissioner;
solicitor (律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159); (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.leadIn: Any inspector or junior police officer who commits any disciplinary offence specified in paragraph (2), and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: pleads guilty before an appropriate tribunal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is found guilty by an appropriate tribunal,

subsection.continued: may be punished by such tribunal in accordance with these regulations.

subsection.leadIn: The offences against discipline are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: absence from duty without leave or good cause;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sleeping on duty;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: cowardice in the performance of duty;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: contravention of police regulations, or any police orders, whether written or verbal;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: insubordination;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: being unfit for duty through intoxication;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: neglect of duty or orders;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: malingering;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: making a statement which is false in a material particular in the course of his duty or in connexion with the discharge by the police force of any of its duties or functions;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: unlawful or unnecessary exercise of authority resulting in loss or injury to any other person or to the Government;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: wilful destruction or negligent loss of or injury to Government property;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: conduct likely to bring the public service into disrepute. (L.N. 59 of 2012)

part.name: P1A
part.heading: Junior Police Officers and Inspectors—Minor Offences

section.name: s3A
section.heading: Interpretation in this Part
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part—
section.def: appointed officer (受委人員) means an officer appointed under regulation 3B(2) to conduct proceedings under this Part;
appropriate officer (適當人員) means, where the alleged offender is a junior police officer, a superintendent, and where the alleged offender is an inspector, a senior police officer;

minor offence (輕微違紀行為) means a disciplinary offence which, having regard to the alleged offender’s record and the circumstances of the case, as established to the satisfaction of an appropriate officer, would, if admitted, merit no punishment under these regulations other than a written admonishment.

subsection.content: Where it appears to an appropriate officer that there is a prima facie case of a minor offence on the part of an inspector or junior police officer, a statement of the facts in respect thereof may be entered on a document entitled Minor Offences Report which shall be the record of the case against such inspector or junior police officer.

A senior police officer shall appoint a superintendent to conduct proceedings under this Part against an alleged offender who is an inspector and a superintendent shall appoint an inspector to conduct proceedings under this Part against an alleged offender who is a junior police officer.

The alleged offender shall appear before the appointed officer in person and shall be called upon to admit or deny the statement of facts in respect of the alleged minor offence and shall be advised that if he admits the facts he will receive a written admonishment. (L.N. 59 of 2012)
If the alleged offender admits the facts the appointed officer shall endorse the Minor Offences Report accordingly and issue a written admonishment to the offender.
If the alleged offender denies the facts the appointed officer shall endorse the Minor Offences Report accordingly and return it to the appropriate officer.

If a Minor Offences Report is returned to the appropriate officer under paragraph (3), a charge or charges shall be heard, in the case of an alleged offender who is a junior police officer, under Part II, and in the case of an alleged offender who is an inspector, under Part III.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Junior Police Officers: Investigation into Disciplinary Offences, Punishment and Appeals

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a single police officer not below the rank of superintendent appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a board appointed by the Commissioner.

subsection.content: If the appropriate tribunal is to be a board appointed by the Commissioner, the Commissioner must appoint a board consisting of a superintendent and a chief inspector, and name the superintendent as the President of the board.

A senior police officer may apply to the Commissioner to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal, and on the application the Commissioner may either appoint a board under paragraph (2) or refer the case back to that senior police officer to be heard by a single police officer not below the rank of superintendent appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer.

No person who originates a complaint leading to a charge or assists in the investigation of the complaint may act as the appropriate tribunal or become a member of the appropriate tribunal hearing the charge.

If it appears to a police officer of or above the rank of sergeant that a disciplinary charge should be laid against a junior police officer subordinate to him or her in rank, the appropriate charge intended to be laid against the junior police officer must be entered in the Defaulter Report, and the junior police officer must be informed of the intended charge as soon as practicable.

subsection.leadIn: If a disciplinary charge is laid against a junior police officer, a senior police officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct that the charge be heard by an appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to the Commissioner to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: The junior police officer must be served with a notice in writing specifying—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the charge;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: (if the charge is to be heard before an appropriate tribunal consisting of a board) the names of the persons constituting the board;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the place of the hearing; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the time and date of the hearing, which must not be earlier than 7 clear days after service of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If a defaulter objects to an appropriate tribunal on the grounds of partiality or bias—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: (where the appropriate tribunal is a superintendent appointed by a senior police officer) the defaulter may, within 7 days from the date of service of a notice under regulation 5(3), apply to the senior police officer for—

subparagraph.content: an application to be made under regulation 5(2)(b) for the Commissioner’s direction that the case be heard by a board instead of by a single police officer; or
the appointment of another appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: (where the appropriate tribunal is not a superintendent appointed by a senior police officer) the defaulter may, within 7 days from the date of service of a notice under regulation 5(3), apply to the Commissioner—

subparagraph.content: to direct that the case be heard by a board instead of by a single police officer; or
to change any single police officer appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer or to change a member of the board appointed by the Commissioner.

subsection.leadIn: A senior police officer may, on receiving an application made under paragraph (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reject the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to the Commissioner to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: appoint another appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, on receiving an application made under paragraph (1)(b) or (2)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reject the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that the case be heard by a board appointed by the Commissioner instead of by a single police officer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: appoint another appropriate tribunal.

subsection.content: An application under paragraph (1) must be made in writing, and the hearing must not be commenced before the determination of the application.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Access to records and documents
section.text: A defaulter must be given copies of or reasonable access to any police records and other documents which the defaulter requires, and are necessary to enable the defaulter to prepare the defence, but not including those records for which the Government claims privilege.

section.name: s7A
section.heading: Appointment of prosecutor
section.text: The Commissioner must appoint a prosecutor for the purposes of proceedings against a defaulter under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: A defaulter may be represented at a hearing by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an inspector, or a junior police officer, of the defaulter’s choice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other police officer of the defaulter’s choice who is a barrister or solicitor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (subject to the Commissioner’s approval) a barrister or solicitor who is not a police officer; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other person of the defaulter’s choice who is approved by the Commissioner for the purpose,

subsection.continued: and the person specified in subparagraph (a), (b), (c) or (d) may conduct the defence on the defaulter’s behalf.

subsection.content: If the Commissioner gives approval under paragraph (1)(c), the defaulter may be represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor of the defaulter’s choice.
Despite paragraph (1), a defaulter must attend a hearing in person.
If a defaulter is represented at a hearing by a barrister or solicitor, the appropriate tribunal and the prosecutor may separately be assisted by a barrister or solicitor at the hearing.
At the hearing, the appropriate tribunal must read to the defaulter any charge against him or her.
The defaulter must plead in person guilty or not guilty to the charge, or to each charge separately if there is more than one, unequivocally.
The appropriate tribunal must enter the plea or pleas on the official record of proceedings.

If a defaulter pleads not guilty at a hearing and evidence for the prosecution is called, witnesses are to be called in support of the charge and, at the conclusion of the evidence of each of those witnesses, the defaulter or the defence representative may cross-examine that witness, who may then be re-examined.

When the examination of all witnesses in support of the charge has been completed, the defaulter or the defence representative may address the appropriate tribunal for the purpose only of showing that no prima facie case has been established.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the appropriate tribunal that there is a prima facie case, it must ask if the defaulter wishes to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: call witnesses.

subsection.content: If the defaulter gives evidence, the defaulter may be cross-examined and re-examined, and any witness called by the defaulter may be examined, cross-examined and re-examined.
At the close of the defence case, witnesses may be called with the consent of the appropriate tribunal to give evidence in rebuttal, and may be examined, cross-examined and re-examined.

At the conclusion of all the evidence, the prosecutor or any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may address the appropriate tribunal and then the defaulter or the defence representative may address the appropriate tribunal in reply.

subsection.leadIn: The appropriate tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call witnesses; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ask any witness any question,

subsection.continued: that it considers may assist it in determining the case.

subsection.content: Evidence must not be taken on oath or affirmation.
The defaulter, the defence representative, the prosecutor and any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may inspect any exhibit produced to the appropriate tribunal by a witness.

The appropriate tribunal may adjourn the hearing from time to time, and if an application is made for an adjournment, the applicant must show to the satisfaction of the appropriate tribunal that the adjournment would serve the ends of justice.
An adjournment granted under paragraph (10) must be for a reasonable period only.
The prosecutor may amend a charge or add a further charge at any time before the appropriate tribunal communicates a finding to the defaulter.
The appropriate tribunal must read and explain any amended or new charge to the defaulter.

subsection.leadIn: The defaulter must plead in person to the amended or new charge, or to each amended or new charge separately if there is more than one, and he or she—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is entitled to a reasonable adjournment to prepare a further defence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may recall any witness; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may call any further witness as he or she thinks fit.

subsection.content: A witness giving evidence under this regulation may be cross-examined and re-examined.
The appropriate tribunal must make, or cause to be made, a written record of the proceedings of a hearing, and the record is to form part of the Defaulter Report.
The appropriate tribunal may make, or cause to be made, an audio recording or an audio and visual recording of the proceedings, or any part of the proceedings, of a hearing.

The appropriate tribunal may at the conclusion of the hearing announce its finding on a charge or reserve its finding, and if the finding is reserved, the appropriate tribunal must call the defaulter to appear in person before it when it announces its finding.
The appropriate tribunal must endorse the finding on the Defaulter Report.

If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the appropriate tribunal must ask if the defaulter wishes to make or produce to the appropriate tribunal a statement which contains any relevant matters that the defaulter wishes to be taken into consideration by the appropriate tribunal.

If the appropriate tribunal consists of a single police officer (single member tribunal) and the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the single member tribunal may then announce its award or reserve its award, and if the award is reserved, the single member tribunal must call the defaulter to appear in person before it when it announces its award.
The single member tribunal must endorse the award on the Defaulter Report.
The single member tribunal must send the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer.

subsection.leadIn: If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty and the single member tribunal considers that no punishment should be awarded, it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the Defaulter Report to that effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inform the defaulter of the acts mentioned in subparagraphs (a) and (b).

subsection.leadIn: If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty and the single member tribunal considers that the punishment it can award is insufficient, it must not make an award, and it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the Defaulter Report to that effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inform the defaulter of the acts mentioned in subparagraphs (a) and (b).

section.name: s11B
section.heading: Board tribunal to send Defaulter Report to Force Discipline Officer
section.text: If the appropriate tribunal consists of a board appointed by the Commissioner and the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the appropriate tribunal must send the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer and inform the defaulter of that fact.

subsection.content: The appropriate tribunal hearing a case may, at any time within 7 days after having announced its finding or award to the defaulter, review the case and arrive at a fresh finding or award which, subject to paragraph (3), is to be substituted for the original finding or award.
If the appropriate tribunal reviews a case, it must announce before the defaulter or communicate in writing to the defaulter its finding or award after the review.

subsection.leadIn: The appropriate tribunal must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substitute for a finding of not guilty a finding of guilty; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: award a greater punishment,

subsection.continued: unless the defaulter is given an opportunity of making representations as to why the original finding should not be varied or the original punishment should not be increased.

subsection.leadIn: The appropriate tribunal must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse its finding or award after the review on the Defaulter Report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer.

subsection.leadIn: A review under this regulation is at the sole discretion of the appropriate tribunal and may be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the appropriate tribunal’s own motion; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on application to the appropriate tribunal in writing by either the prosecutor or the defaulter.

section.name: s12A
section.heading: Proceedings in defaulter’s absence
section.text: Where a defaulter is required to appear in person in any proceedings under this Part and repeatedly fails to appear, the appropriate tribunal may proceed in the defaulter’s absence if satisfied that the defaulter has no reasonable excuse for the failures.

subsection.leadIn: A junior police officer who has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence before or by an appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer may, subject to regulation 30, be awarded any of the following punishments by the appropriate tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: caution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reprimand;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: severe reprimand;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: deferment or stoppage of increment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: forfeiture of not more than 1 month’s pay except in the case of absence without good cause when forfeiture of pay extends to the period of absence in addition to any other punishment awarded;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: reduction in rank;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: an order to resign immediately without salary in lieu of notice;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: compulsory retirement with full retirement benefits or reduced retirement benefits or without retirement benefits;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: dismissal without retirement benefits.

subsection.content: If a junior police officer has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence before or by an appropriate tribunal, and the appropriate tribunal sends the Defaulter Report to the Force Discipline Officer under regulation 11A(4)(b) or (5)(b) or 11B, the junior police officer may, subject to regulation 14, be awarded a punishment that the Force Discipline Officer is empowered to award under regulation 30.

If a Defaulter Report is sent to the Force Discipline Officer under regulation 11A(4)(b) or (5)(b) or 11B, and the Force Discipline Officer is of the opinion that the junior police officer does not deserve to be punished but that the proceedings disclose grounds for requiring the junior police officer to retire in the public interest, the Force Discipline Officer may, without further proceedings, require the junior police officer to retire in the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: Despite this regulation, a junior police officer who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is to be dismissed from the police force by the Commissioner, the Force Discipline Officer or a senior police officer,

subsection.continued: must, if he or she is a station sergeant or sergeant, be reduced to the ranks before the dismissal.

subsection.leadIn: Despite this regulation, a junior police officer who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been ordered by the Commissioner, the Force Discipline Officer or a senior police officer to resign immediately from the police force,

subsection.continued: must, if he or she fails to comply with the order, be dismissed without retirement benefits.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Confirmation or variation of finding or award and making of award by Force Discipline Officer

subsection.leadIn: Within 14 days from the receipt of a Default Report by the Force Discipline Officer under regulation 11A(3), (4)(b) or (5)(b), 11B or 12(4)(b), the Force Discipline Officer must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: confirm the finding;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: vary the finding and substitute any finding which the appropriate tribunal could have made on the evidence adduced; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: subject to paragraph (2)(c), set aside the finding and order a rehearing of the case on the same or other charges by another appropriate tribunal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in respect of any award, if the Force Discipline Officer confirms or varies the finding—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if no punishment was awarded, award a punishment that the Force Discipline Officer is empowered to award;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: confirm the award;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: remit the award; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: subject to paragraph (2)(a) and (b), substitute any other award that the Force Discipline Officer is empowered to award.

subsection.leadIn: The Force Discipline Officer must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substitute for any punishment awarded any greater punishment unless the defaulter is given an opportunity of making representations to the Force Discipline Officer as to why the original punishment should not be increased;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substitute for a finding of not guilty a finding of guilty; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order a rehearing if the finding, as confirmed or varied, is one of not guilty.

subsection.content: The Force Discipline Officer acting under this regulation must announce before the defaulter or communicate in writing to the defaulter the action taken by the Force Discipline Officer.

A junior police officer may within 14 days from the announcement to him or her by, or the receipt of a communication from, the Force Discipline Officer of a finding, decision or award, appeal in writing to the Commissioner by petition, which may contain any representations relevant to the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal under this regulation, the Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: remit any award;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: substitute any other award that the Commissioner is empowered to award; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the Commissioner is of the opinion that the junior police officer does not deserve to be punished but that the proceedings disclose grounds for requiring the junior police officer to retire in the public interest, without further proceedings, require the junior police officer to retire in the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal under this regulation, the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: must announce before the defaulter or communicate in writing to the defaulter the outcome of the appeal or the action taken under this regulation.

subsection.content: If an appeal is lodged under this regulation, any punishment awarded (other than a caution, reprimand or severe reprimand) must be suspended pending the determination of the appeal.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Inspectors: Investigation into Disciplinary Offences, Punishment and Appeals

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part—
subsection.def: appropriate tribunal (適當審裁體) means—(a)a single police officer not below the rank of superintendent appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer;(b)a board appointed by the Commissioner; or(c)a board appointed by the Secretary for the Civil Service.

subsection.content: If the appropriate tribunal is to be a board appointed by the Commissioner, the Commissioner must appoint a board consisting of 2 police officers of or above the rank of superintendent, and name one of them as the President of the board.

A senior police officer may apply to the Commissioner to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal, and on the application the Commissioner may, subject to paragraphs (4) and (5), either appoint a board under paragraph (2) or refer the case back to that senior police officer to be heard by a single police officer not below the rank of superintendent appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer.

On an application under paragraph (3), if the Commissioner is of the opinion that there are exceptional circumstances in the case, the Commissioner must request the Secretary for the Civil Service to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal.

On an application under paragraph (3), if the Commissioner is of the opinion that there are no exceptional circumstances in the case, but the defaulter so requests, the Commissioner must refer the request to the Secretary for the Civil Service to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal.

In exercising the discretion whether or not to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal, the Secretary for the Civil Service must take into account any representations made in writing by the Commissioner and the defaulter.

If the appropriate tribunal is to be a board appointed by the Secretary for the Civil Service, the Secretary for the Civil Service must appoint a board consisting of 3 public officers, and name one of them as the President of the board.

No person who originates a complaint leading to a charge or assists in the investigation of the complaint may act as the appropriate tribunal or become a member of the appropriate tribunal hearing the charge.

If it appears to a senior police officer that a disciplinary charge should be laid against an inspector, the appropriate charge intended to be laid against the inspector must be entered in the Defaulter Report.

subsection.leadIn: If a disciplinary charge is laid against an inspector, the senior police officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct that the charge be heard by an appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to the Commissioner to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: The inspector must be served with a notice in writing specifying—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the charge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the charge is to be heard before an appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer) the name of the officer constituting the appropriate tribunal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (if the charge is to be heard before an appropriate tribunal consisting of a board) the names of the persons constituting the board;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the place of the hearing; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the time and date of the hearing, which must not be earlier than 7 clear days after service of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If a defaulter objects to an appropriate tribunal on the grounds of partiality or bias, the defaulter may, within 7 days from the date of service of a notice under regulation 17(3), apply to the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to change any single police officer appointed by the Commissioner or by a senior police officer or to change a member of the board appointed by the Commissioner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to request the Secretary for the Civil Service to appoint a board to be the appropriate tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, on receiving an application made under paragraph (1)(a) or (b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reject the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that the case be heard by a board appointed by the Commissioner instead of by a single police officer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: appoint another appropriate tribunal.

subsection.content: If the defaulter has made an application under paragraph (1)(c), the Commissioner must refer the request to the Secretary for the Civil Service in accordance with regulation 16(5) as if that regulation applied.
An application under paragraph (1) must be made in writing, and the hearing must not be commenced before the determination of the application.

section.name: s18A
section.heading: Access to records and documents
section.content: A defaulter must be given copies of or reasonable access to any police records and other documents which the defaulter requires, and are necessary to enable the defaulter to prepare the defence, but not including those records for which the Government claims privilege.

section.name: s18B
section.heading: Appointment of prosecutor
section.content: The Commissioner must appoint a prosecutor for the purposes of proceedings against a defaulter under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: A defaulter may be represented at a hearing by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an inspector of the defaulter’s choice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other police officer of the defaulter’s choice who is a barrister or solicitor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (subject to the Commissioner’s approval) a barrister or solicitor who is not a police officer; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other person of the defaulter’s choice who is approved by the Commissioner for the purpose,

subsection.continued: and the person specified in subparagraph (a), (b), (c) or (d) may conduct the defence on the defaulter’s behalf.

subsection.content: If the Commissioner gives approval under paragraph (1)(c), the defaulter may be represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor of the defaulter’s choice.
Despite paragraph (1), a defaulter must attend a hearing in person.
If a defaulter is represented at a hearing by a barrister or solicitor, the appropriate tribunal and the prosecutor may separately be assisted by a barrister or solicitor at the hearing.
At the hearing, the appropriate tribunal must read to the defaulter any charge against him or her.
The defaulter must plead in person guilty or not guilty to the charge, or to each charge separately if there is more than one, unequivocally.
The appropriate tribunal must enter the plea or pleas on the official record of proceedings.

If a defaulter pleads not guilty at a hearing and evidence for the prosecution is called, witnesses are to be called in support of the charge and, at the conclusion of the evidence of each of those witnesses, the defaulter or the defence representative may cross-examine that witness, who may then be re-examined.

When the examination of all witnesses in support of the charge has been completed, the defaulter or the defence representative may address the appropriate tribunal for the purpose only of showing that no prima facie case has been established.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the appropriate tribunal that there is a prima facie case, it must ask if the defaulter wishes to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: call witnesses.

subsection.content: If the defaulter gives evidence, the defaulter may be cross-examined and re-examined, and any witness called by the defaulter may be examined, cross-examined and re-examined.
At the close of the defence case, witnesses may be called with the consent of the appropriate tribunal to give evidence in rebuttal, and may be examined, cross-examined and re-examined.

At the conclusion of all the evidence, the prosecutor or any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may address the appropriate tribunal and then the defaulter or the defence representative may address the appropriate tribunal in reply.

subsection.leadIn: The appropriate tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call witnesses; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ask any witness any question,

subsection.continued: that it considers may assist it in determining the case.

subsection.content: Evidence must not be taken on oath or affirmation.
The defaulter, the defence representative, the prosecutor and any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may inspect any exhibit produced to the appropriate tribunal by a witness.

The appropriate tribunal may adjourn the hearing from time to time, and if an application is made for an adjournment, the applicant must show to the satisfaction of the appropriate tribunal that the adjournment would serve the ends of justice.
An adjournment granted under paragraph (10) must be for a reasonable period only.
The prosecutor may amend a charge or add a further charge at any time before the appropriate tribunal communicates a finding to the defaulter.
The appropriate tribunal must read and explain any amended or new charge to the defaulter.

subsection.leadIn: The defaulter must plead in person to the amended or new charge, or to each amended or new charge separately if there is more than one, and he or she—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is entitled to a reasonable adjournment to prepare a further defence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may recall any witness; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may call any further witness as he or she thinks fit.

subsection.content: A witness giving evidence under this regulation may be cross-examined and re-examined.
The appropriate tribunal must make, or cause to be made, a written record of the proceedings of a hearing, and the record is to form part of the Defaulter Report.
The appropriate tribunal may make, or cause to be made, an audio recording or an audio and visual recording of the proceedings, or any part of the proceedings, of a hearing.

The appropriate tribunal may at the conclusion of the hearing announce its finding on a charge or reserve its finding, and if the finding is reserved, the appropriate tribunal must call the defaulter to appear in person before it when it announces its finding.
The appropriate tribunal must endorse the finding on the Defaulter Report.

If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the appropriate tribunal must ask if the defaulter wishes to make or produce to the appropriate tribunal a statement which contains any relevant matters that the defaulter wishes to be taken into consideration by the appropriate tribunal.

If the appropriate tribunal consists of a single police officer (single member tribunal) and the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the single member tribunal may then announce its award or reserve its award, and if the award is reserved, the single member tribunal must call the defaulter to appear in person before it when it announces its award.
The single member tribunal must endorse the award on the Defaulter Report.

subsection.leadIn: If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty and the single member tribunal considers that no punishment should be awarded, it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the Defaulter Report to that effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inform the defaulter of the endorsement.

subsection.leadIn: If the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty and the single member tribunal considers that the punishment it can award is insufficient, it must not make an award, and it must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the Defaulter Report to that effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the Defaulter Report to the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inform the defaulter of the acts mentioned in subparagraphs (a) and (b).

section.name: s23B
section.heading: Board tribunal to send Defaulter Report to Commissioner
section.content: If the appropriate tribunal consists of a board appointed by the Commissioner or by the Secretary for the Civil Service and the defaulter has pleaded guilty or is found guilty, the appropriate tribunal must send the Defaulter Report to the Commissioner and inform the defaulter of that fact.

section.name: s23C
section.heading: Award or reference to Chief Executive by Commissioner

subsection.leadIn: If a case is referred to the Commissioner under regulation 23A(4)(b) or 23B, the Commissioner may make an award, and must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the award on the Defaulter Report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: announce the award before the defaulter or communicate it in writing to the defaulter.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner considers that the punishment which the Commissioner can award is insufficient, the Commissioner must not make an award, and the Commissioner must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endorse the Defaulter Report to that effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forward the Defaulter Report to the Chief Executive under regulation 27; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: inform the defaulter of the acts mentioned in subparagraphs (a) and (b).

subsection.content: The appropriate tribunal hearing a case may, at any time within 7 days after having announced its finding or award to the defaulter, review the case and arrive at a fresh finding or award which, subject to paragraph (3), is to be substituted for the original finding or award.
If the appropriate tribunal reviews a case, it must announce before the defaulter or communicate in writing to the defaulter its finding or award after the review.

subsection.leadIn: The appropriate tribunal must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substitute for a finding of not guilty a finding of guilty; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: award a greater punishment,

subsection.continued: unless the defaulter is given an opportunity of making representations as to why the original finding should not be varied or the original punishment should not be increased.

subsection.content: The appropriate tribunal must endorse its finding or award after the review on the Defaulter Report.

subsection.leadIn: A review under this regulation is at the sole discretion of the appropriate tribunal and may be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the appropriate tribunal’s own motion; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on application to the appropriate tribunal in writing by either the prosecutor or the defaulter.

section.name: s24A
section.heading: Proceedings in defaulter’s absence
section.content: Where a defaulter is required to appear in person in any proceedings under this Part and repeatedly fails to appear, the appropriate tribunal may proceed in the defaulter’s absence if satisfied that the defaulter has no reasonable excuse for the failures.

subsection.leadIn: An inspector who has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence before or by an appropriate tribunal consisting of a single police officer may, subject to regulation 30, be punished by the appropriate tribunal with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: caution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reprimand.

subsection.leadIn: In place of or in addition to a punishment under paragraph (1), an inspector may be punished by the Commissioner with—

paragraph.name: a
b
ba
paragraph.content: severe reprimand; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: deferment or stoppage of increment; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: forfeiture of not more than 1 month’s pay except in the case of absence without good cause when forfeiture of pay extends to the period of absence in addition to any other punishment awarded.

subsection.content: If a case is referred to the Commissioner under regulation 23A(4)(b) or 23B, the Commissioner may award any of the punishments referred to in paragraphs (1) and (2).

subsection.leadIn: An inspector may within 14 days from the announcement to him or her by, or the receipt of a communication from, the Commissioner or an appropriate tribunal of a finding or award—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (if the appropriate tribunal was a board appointed by the Commissioner or by the Secretary for the Civil Service) appeal in writing to the Chief Executive by petition, which may contain any representations relevant to the appeal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in any other case) appeal in writing to the Commissioner by petition, which may contain any representations relevant to the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: An inspector who has appealed to the Commissioner under paragraph (1)(b) and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been awarded a punishment by the Commissioner under regulation 25(2) or (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is aggrieved by any other decision made by the Commissioner,

subsection.continued: may, within 14 days from the receipt of communication of the award or decision, appeal in writing to the Chief Executive by petition, which may contain any representations relevant to the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal under paragraph (1) or (2), the Chief Executive may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: set aside a finding if in all the circumstances of the case the Chief Executive considers justice so requires and either—

subparagraph.content: award a punishment warranted by any finding which has not been set aside; or
award no punishment if that finding does not exist;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: confirm or remit an award;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: substitute any other award that the Commissioner could have awarded under regulation 25;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: confirm, vary or revoke any other decision made by the Commissioner; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: order a rehearing of the case on the same or other charges by another appropriate tribunal.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive’s decision on an appeal under paragraph (1) or (2) or on a reference under regulation 27 must be communicated to the Commissioner and to the inspector by the Chief Executive’s Office.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, on an appeal under paragraph (1) or of the Commissioner’s own motion—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: confirm or remit an award;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: substitute any other award that the Commissioner could have awarded under regulation 25, except that no greater punishment may be awarded unless the inspector is given an opportunity of making representations as to why the original punishment should not be increased;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: order a rehearing of the case on the same or other charges by another appropriate tribunal.

subsection.content: If an appeal is lodged under this regulation, any punishment awarded (other than a caution, reprimand or severe reprimand) must be suspended pending the determination of the appeal.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Commissioner may report to Chief Executive

subsection.leadIn: If an inspector has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence and it appears to the Commissioner that the nature of the offence is so aggravated and other relevant circumstances are such that dismissal without retirement benefits, or compulsory retirement with full retirement benefits or reduced retirement benefits or without retirement benefits is merited, the Commissioner must forward to the Chief Executive the Defaulter Report together with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the record of the inspector’s service;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Commissioner’s recommendation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Commissioner’s reasons for not making an award under regulation 25(2) or (3). (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.content: The Commissioner must at the same time as the Defaulter Report is forwarded under paragraph (1) inform the inspector that his or her case will be considered by the Chief Executive, and the inspector may within 14 days from the receipt of the information, or within any extended period of time that the Chief Executive may allow, forward to the Chief Executive a petition in writing, containing any representations which may be relevant to enable the Chief Executive to exercise a discretion under paragraph (3). (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.leadIn: Where any report is forwarded to the Chief Executive under this regulation, the Chief Executive may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that the inspector be dismissed without retirement benefits; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if in all the circumstances of the case he considers justice so requires, set aside any finding of an appropriate tribunal and order that the inspector be dismissed without retirement benefits if in his opinion such punishment is warranted by any finding which has not been set aside; or

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: if in all the circumstances of the case, he is of the opinion that the misconduct of the inspector is serious enough to warrant the compulsory retirement of the inspector, order that the inspector be compulsorily retired with full retirement benefits or reduced retirement benefits or without retirement benefits; or (L.N. 305 of 1982)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: remit the case to the Commissioner and the Commissioner may then award any punishment which he has power to award under regulation 25, but where the Commissioner awards any punishment under this paragraph, regulation 26(2) shall apply as if such punishment had been awarded under regulation 25; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if he is of the opinion that the inspector does not deserve to be punished but that the proceedings disclose grounds for requiring the inspector to retire in the public interest, without further proceedings require him to retire in the public interest. (L.N. 23 of 1978; 6 of 2009 s. 9)

editorialNote.content: This regulation was amended by section 9 of the Disciplined Services Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 2009 (6 of 2009). Please see the transitional provisions contained in section 30 of that Amendment Ordinance.

section.name: s27A
section.heading: Joint proceedings against inspectors and junior police officers

subsection.leadIn: Where one or more inspectors and one or more junior police officers are charged with a disciplinary offence or offences arising out of the same facts, the Commissioner or a senior police officer may direct that the defaulters be charged and proceeded against jointly at the same proceedings unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one of the defaulters objects to the appropriate tribunal on the grounds of partiality or bias; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one of the defaulters objects to joint proceedings on the grounds of disparity of rank.

subsection.content: Joint proceedings under this regulation shall be dealt with as if they were proceedings against an inspector under Part III.

Subject to this regulation, any punishment awarded by an appropriate tribunal may be suspended by that tribunal or by any police officer of higher rank than the officer or officers constituting the tribunal for a period of not less than 6 months nor more than 1 year.

Subject to paragraph (3), where any punishment has been suspended under this regulation the appropriate tribunal or any police officer of higher rank shall at the expiration of the period of suspension review the case or may, at any time during the period of suspension, review the case, taking into consideration such reports on the conduct of the defaulter during the period of suspension as may be available.

subsection.leadIn: On a review under paragraph (2), the appropriate tribunal or officer of higher rank may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remit or reduce the punishment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order the punishment to be executed immediately. (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: If the appropriate tribunal or officer of higher rank remits or reduces the punishment, the appropriate tribunal or officer of higher rank must cause any entry relating to the disciplinary offence which has been made in the records of the defaulter to be expunged or altered accordingly. (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.content: If, during the period of suspension of a punishment under this regulation, the defaulter is convicted of another disciplinary offence committed after the disciplinary offence for which the suspended punishment was awarded, the suspended punishment must be executed immediately and any punishment on that other disciplinary offence must not be suspended. (L.N. 59 of 2012)
This regulation shall not affect the lodging and hearing of an appeal.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Payment for loss or damage to property

subsection.leadIn: If an inspector or a junior police officer has pleaded guilty to or is found guilty of a disciplinary offence before or by an appropriate tribunal, the appropriate tribunal may, in addition to or in lieu of any punishment it is by these regulations empowered to award, order the defaulter to pay in full or in part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any article of clothing, equipment or property that has been entrusted or supplied to the defaulter in his or her capacity as a police officer which has been lost or damaged;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any Government property lost or damaged by the defaulter; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the compensation paid, ex gratia or otherwise, by the Government to any person in respect of the loss or damage of that person’s property by the defaulter,

subsection.continued: but may do so only if the loss or damage has resulted from the defaulter’s neglect or fault, and the amount ordered to be paid does not exceed his or her salary for 1 month. (L.N. 59 of 2012)

subsection.leadIn: A gazetted officer may require an inspector or junior police officer to pay to the Government in full or in part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any article of clothing, equipment or property whatsoever entrusted to the inspector or junior police officer in his capacity as police officer and lost or damaged by him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any Government property lost or damaged by him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the compensation paid, ex gratia or otherwise, by the Government to any person in respect of the loss or damage of that person’s property by the inspector or junior police officer,

subsection.continued: in each case only if the loss or damage has resulted from the junior police officer’s or inspector’s neglect or fault and the amount ordered to be paid does not exceed his salary for one month.

subsection.content: For the purposes of enabling due inquiry to be made as to whether any police officer should be required to pay any amount under paragraph (2), affording the police officer due opportunity to make representations and enabling a requirement under that paragraph to be appealed against and reviewed, Parts II and III apply, with the necessary modifications, to and in respect of that requirement as they apply to and in respect of a finding of guilty of a disciplinary offence and an award of punishment for the offence. (L.N. 59 of 2012)

section.name: s29A
section.heading: Seizure and detention of property required as exhibit

subsection.content: A police officer of the rank of sergeant or above may seize and detain any property which he reasonably suspects to be the property of a police officer that may be required for the purpose of proving a disciplinary offence.

subsection.leadIn: Any property seized and detained under paragraph (1) and which is not admitted in evidence as an exhibit in disciplinary proceedings shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the owner thereof is not known, be forfeited and disposed of in accordance with paragraph (3) or (4) as the case may be; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the owner thereof is known, be returned to the owner.

subsection.content: Any property seized and detained under this regulation the ownership of which is not known shall be disposed of in such manner as the Commissioner may determine and, if sold, after the deduction of expenses necessarily incurred in the sale, the proceeds of sale (if any) shall be paid into the general revenue. (L.N. 253 of 1999)
Any money seized and detained under this regulation the owner of which is not known shall be paid into the general revenue. (L.N. 253 of 1999)
An appropriate tribunal may, in addition to any award made in any proceedings, order the forfeiture of any property admitted in evidence as an exhibit.

Property ordered to be forfeited under paragraph (1) shall, after the award has been confirmed and any appeal determined, be disposed of in such manner as the Commissioner shall determine and, if sold, after the deduction of expenses necessarily incurred in the sale, the proceeds of sale (if any) shall be paid into the general revenue.
Money ordered to be forfeited under paragraph (1) shall, after the award has been confirmed and any appeal determined, be paid into the general revenue.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Awards
section.text: The punishment that may be awarded by an inspector, a superintendent, a senior police officer, the Force Discipline Officer, the Commissioner and the Chief Executive respectively shall be those set out in the Schedule.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Effect of award
section.content: Subject to regulation 28, an award of punishment made under these regulations shall take effect from the date of announcement or communication to the defaulter of the award.

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (2), the amendments made by the amendment regulation do not apply to proceedings under these regulations conducted in respect of a defaulter on whom a notice was served before the commencement date under regulation 5(2) or 17(4) or (5) of the pre-amended regulations, and the pre-amended regulations apply in respect of those proceedings as if those amendments had not been made.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the addition of the definitions of barrister, defence representative, disciplinary offence, hearing and solicitor under section 3 of the amendment regulation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following sections of the amendment regulation—

subparagraph.content: section 7, which amends regulation 3C (procedure for minor offences) of the pre-amended regulations;
section 13, which adds regulation 7B (representation of defaulter at hearing) to these regulations;
section 21, which adds regulation 12A (proceedings in defaulter’s absence) to these regulations;
section 38, which adds regulation 24A (proceedings in defaulter’s absence) to these regulations; and
section 43(2), which substitutes regulation 29(3) of these regulations for regulation 29(3) of the pre-amended regulations.

subsection.leadIn: In this regulation—
subsection.def: amendment regulation (《修訂規例》) means the Police (Discipline) (Amendment) Regulation 2012 (L.N. 59 of 2012);
*commencement date (生效日期) means the commencement date of the amendment regulation appointed under section 1 of the amendment regulation;
pre-amended regulations (《修訂前規例》) means the Police (Discipline) Regulations (Cap. 232 sub. leg. A) as in force immediately before the commencement date.
